quote.msg:
ä¿¾é¡Œlinear algebraå¤§å®¶ç©å“
Let A be an n x n matrix with real number (or any other fields) entries. Suppose there is another n x n matrix B with real number entries such that AB = I, where I is the n x n identity matrix. Prove that BA = I.
å°æ–¼algebraäººåšŸè¬›ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è«—åŸ‹:
Give an example of a noncommutative ring such that AB = I => BA = I does not necessarily hold.

replies.msg:
consider BA = C
ABA = AC
A = AC as AB = I
A - AC = 0
A(I - C) = 0
As AB = I, A is not equal to 0
then, I - C = 0
therefore, C = I (i.e. BA = I )

quote.msg:
ä¿¾é¡Œlinear algebraå¤§å®¶ç©å“

å°æ–¼algebraäººåšŸè¬›ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è«—åŸ‹:

consider BA = C
ABA = AC
A = AC as AB = I
A - AC = 0
A(I - C) = 0
As AB = I, A is not equal to 0
then, I - C = 0
therefore, C = I (i.e. BA = I )

replies.msg:
AB = I, det(AB) = det(A)det(B) = det(I) = 0
det(A) and det(B) ≠ 0
Aâ»¹ and Bâ»¹ exist
(AB)â»¹ = Bâ»¹Aâ»¹ = Iâ»¹ = I
post-multiply AB to both sides
(Bâ»¹Aâ»¹)AB = IAB = AB
Bâ»¹(Aâ»¹A)B = Bâ»¹(I)B = Bâ»¹B = I = AB

replies.msg:
è«—åˆ°é»æ¨£è¬›åŸ‹ä½¢å””æœƒæœ‰zero divisor

Since AB=I, B has full rank (proof ez).

Our goal is to show BA=I.
Notice that B=BI = BAB.
So BABx=Bx for all x in F^n.

As B is a n by n matrix with full rank, every vector y in F^n can be written as y= Bx.

Thus, BABx=Bx
=>BAy=y for all y in F^n
=> BAy=Iy
=> BA=I.

å°æ–¼algebraäººåšŸè¬›ï¼Œå¯ä»¥è«—åŸ‹:
Give an example of a noncommutative ring such that AB = I => BA = I does not necessarily hold.

det(A) and det(B) ≠ 0
Aâ»¹ and Bâ»¹ exist
(AB)â»¹ = Bâ»¹Aâ»¹ = Iâ»¹ = I
post-multiply AB to both sides
(Bâ»¹Aâ»¹)AB = IAB = AB
Bâ»¹(Aâ»¹A)B = Bâ»¹(I)B = Bâ»¹B = I = AB
